Solutions should be fact-based and mindful of diverse journeys of those experiencing homelessness—and businesses have a role in resolving the crisis.</div></div></div></section><main data-layer-region="article-body" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xxl"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__iFmyt mck-o-xs-right-span"><div data-layer-region="downloads-right-rail"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c">DOWNLOADS</h3><div><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="#/download/%2F~%2Fmedia%2Fmckinsey%2Findustries%2Fpublic%20and%20social%20sector%2Four%20insights%2Fhomelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions%2Fhomelessness-in-los-angeles-a-unique-crisis-demanding-new-solution.pdf%3FshouldIndex%3Dfalse" class="DownloadsSidebar_mck-c-downloads-sidebar__download-link__fPqFQ mdc-c-link___lBbY1_990311c" target="_self" data-layer-event-prefix="Download Link" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-report-type="Full Report" data-layer-file-name="homelessness-in-los-angeles-a-unique-crisis-demanding-new-solution" data-layer-report-name="homelessness-in-los-angeles-a-unique-crisis-demanding-new-solution>Full Report"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-download-icon"></span><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Full Report (21 pages)</span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong>Los Angeles County’s homelessness situation</strong> is unlike any other in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="079dd84e-e2a8-4390-8ccf-c6beef7c67ab"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="079dd84e-e2a8-4390-8ccf-c6beef7c67ab" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Analyses of Los Angeles’s homeless population were conducted at the county level, not at the city level.</span></span></span></a></span> By recent estimates, LA’s population of people experiencing homelessness has surpassed New York City’s to become the largest in the nation—and it is still growing, with about one in 150 Angelenos, or 69,000 people, experiencing homelessness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fe2e5d8d-5d01-41bd-8e73-cf6e09517fbb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fe2e5d8d-5d01-41bd-8e73-cf6e09517fbb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“HUD 2022 continuum of care homeless assistance programs homeless populations and subpopulations: NY-600 New York City CoC,” US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), January 25, 2022;
    2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count data summary, Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> By the time LA hosts the 2028 Olympic Games, it is at risk of having more than 100,000 people experiencing homelessness (Exhibit 1). Thousands do not have a safe place to sleep tonight, and more than five people experiencing homelessness (PEH) may lose their lives today.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5b0f1c72-377b-4d00-8fbc-a4b350f84afe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5b0f1c72-377b-4d00-8fbc-a4b350f84afe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Mortality among people experiencing homelessness in Los Angeles County: One year before and after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, Los Angeles County Department of Public Health, April 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body">This report is a collaborative effort by <a href="/our-people/ashwin-adarkar">Ashwin Adarkar</a>, <a href="/our-people/tolian-gjika">Tolian Gjika</a>, <a href="/our-people/tim-ward">Tim Ward</a>, <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b8d840caa-6a65-4626-8ce5-1f9fefe604dd%7d%40en">Jonathan Woetzel</a>, and Yenli Wong.</div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In a region overflowing with diversity, culture, and wealth, understanding the factors contributing to this crisis may help identify potential solutions. Research indicates this crisis is caused not only by a combination of historical factors and modern problems but also by unique challenges in scale, persistence, and lack of shelter. Surfacing the facts and facing the issues related to homelessness head-on can lead to unique ways to address LA’s challenges—and drive the inclusive growth that may prevent this situation from reoccurring in the future.</p>
<h2>Why LA’s homelessness crisis is unique</h2>
<p>LA County is large by almost any measure. It is home to ten million people spread over 4,000 square miles and, if it were a country, its economy would rank among the world’s 25 biggest.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3469dfae-05a4-49ef-a3f8-479aa643ceb4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3469dfae-05a4-49ef-a3f8-479aa643ceb4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“QuickFacts: Los Angeles County, California: Population estimates, July 1 2021,” US Census Bureau, 2021; “Gross domestic product by county, 2021,” Bureau of Economic Analysis, December 8, 2022; “GDP (current US$),” World Bank, accessed March 7, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Unfortunately, LA’s homelessness crisis mirrors this scale and is only exacerbated by its rapid growth rate, the persistence of chronic homelessness, and a lack of shelter.</p>
<h3>Size and complexity: A huge, rapidly growing homeless population in a complicated setup</h3>
<p>LA County’s population, its growth rate, and the vast space and jurisdictions it covers create unique challenges requiring comprehensive, far-reaching solutions. The total number of PEH is growing quickly: it increased by roughly 56 percent from 2015 to 2022, compared with an 18 percent decline in New York City, which previously had the country’s largest homeless population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="59545f39-b481-47a0-8e27-dbce946fab1e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="59545f39-b481-47a0-8e27-dbce946fab1e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">  “HUD 2022 continuum of care,” January 25, 2022; “HUD 2015 continuum of care homeless assistance programs homeless populations and subpopulations: NY-600 New York City CoC,” HUD, January 22, 2015; 2015 Greater Los Angeles homeless count results, Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA), July 2015; LAHSA releases 2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count results, LAHSA, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> And every day matters: on average, for every 207 individuals who exit homelessness daily, 227 more enter—including roughly 16 individuals who return to homelessness after six months (Exhibit 2). The county’s size and complex governance structure complicate efforts further. LA County’s geographic footprint is larger than Delaware and Rhode Island combined.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="260d94ff-919e-4c55-9662-249bebf79aa8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="260d94ff-919e-4c55-9662-249bebf79aa8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“About the county,” Los Angeles County Department of Human Resources, accessed March 7, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, decision making can be quite complex, as LA County is made up of 88 cities, each with its own mayor and city council for a total at the city and county levels of some 550 elected officials.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3a771d9a-5a43-4a4c-86d3-13a266a996cd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3a771d9a-5a43-4a4c-86d3-13a266a996cd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Population estimates, 2020-2021, US Census Bureau, May 26, 2022; “Los Angeles County Division,” League of California Cities, accessed March 7, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh2-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Every day, the homeless population of Los Angeles grows by an estimated 20 people." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh2-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The devastating scale of LA’s problem becomes apparent as one considers some of the deeper implications, like the additional lives lost and the impact on children. If LA’s mortality rate of PEH continues on its current trajectory, the homelessness growth rate implies an additional 16,000 deaths of people experiencing homelessness through 2028.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8f475d6b-7361-4249-832d-a30ed77fa474"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8f475d6b-7361-4249-832d-a30ed77fa474" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on 1,988 PEH deaths recorded postpandemic (April 2020 to March 2021) in LA County; Mortality among people experiencing homelessness in Los Angeles County, April 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Lives of PEH are already cut short by an average of 35 years for women and 28 years for men.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0ebe088f-1c7b-4573-b4db-66771a9a702b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0ebe088f-1c7b-4573-b4db-66771a9a702b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anna Gorman and Harriet Blair Rowan, “The homeless are dying in record numbers on the streets of L.A.,” <em>Kaiser Health News</em>, April 24, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, in 2022, about 10 percent of PEH (roughly 6,000 people) were under the age of 18.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="26e1bee3-6eb8-40ef-a800-4ab46b8cb020"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="26e1bee3-6eb8-40ef-a800-4ab46b8cb020" aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="94c2dce7-2b99-42b4-9747-a400285bd4f1"><sup an estimated PEH population of more than 100,000 in 2028; Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority.</span></span></span></a></span> That is tragic on multiple levels; by age 12, about 80 percent of children experiencing homelessness have been exposed to at least one serious, violent incident.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" <h3>Severity and persistence: Higher rates of chronic homelessness</h3>
<!-- -->
<p>More than 40 percent of people experiencing homelessness in LA—some 29,000 people—are considered chronically homeless,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a5ac9200-bff6-47c0-8668-c2fec089a004"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a5ac9200-bff6-47c0-8668-c2fec089a004" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">HUD defines a person experiencing chronic homelessness as an individual or head of household who has been continuously homeless for one year or more and has had at least four separate episodes of homelessness in the last three years, and has a disabling condition.</span></span></span></a></span> amplifying the complexity of the crisis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8108f7d4-ae5a-4f20-b38c-578b446d6a91"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8108f7d4-ae5a-4f20-b38c-578b446d6a91" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count data summary, LAHSA, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In fact, LA’s chronically homeless population is larger than the nation’s next eight largest chronically homeless populations combined.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="048e1578-7183-4cb0-a0f2-e53dad060c6a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="048e1578-7183-4cb0-a0f2-e53dad060c6a" statistics about the chronically homeless populations for the next eight largest counties/continuums of care are sourced from HUD. “CoC Homeless Populations and Subpopulations Reports,” HUD Exchange, HUD, accessed March 20, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The numbers also keep growing in volume and in cost: LA County’s chronically homeless population grew by more than 50 percent between 2019 and 2020 alone.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="89cb34b6-65e7-4122-8029-9ef6baf66659"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="89cb34b6-65e7-4122-8029-9ef6baf66659" homeless count—Los Angeles County data summary, LAHSA, July 30, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> At current growth rates, LA could have a chronically homeless population the size of the city of Manhattan Beach by 2028. Additionally, this population has historically required more spending on support services than the rest of the population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="00edc7df-88ee-43e7-8d9b-efccbfd275e4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="00edc7df-88ee-43e7-8d9b-efccbfd275e4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The average cost per person for overall county services for the chronically homeless ($7,879) was 21.6 percent higher than the average for the total population in a study of people who had experienced homelessness. Max Stevens and Fei Wu, The services homeless single adults use and their associated costs, LA County, January 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> For instance, the chronically homeless are six times more likely to have a serious mental illness or a physical disability than the nonchronically homeless.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f3a463e3-d93e-4702-92ce-b97d2f55f5a5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f3a463e3-d93e-4702-92ce-b97d2f55f5a5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count—chronic homelessness, LAHSA, September 21, 2022; 2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count—non-chronic homelessness, LAHSA, September 21, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> People who experience chronic homelessness can also be caught in a revolving door of incarceration and crisis services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ce81b4f6-6fef-4e2a-9590-da3036d25c3f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ce81b4f6-6fef-4e2a-9590-da3036d25c3f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Homelessness in America: Focus on chronic homelessness among people with disabilities, United States Interagency Council on Homelessness, August 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Substance use disorders further exacerbate the situation. PEH in LA County are 35 times more likely to die of a drug or alcohol overdose than the general population, with fentanyl’s contribution to PEH deaths increasing from 27 percent of deaths in the year before the COVID-19 pandemic to 45 percent of deaths in the year after the onset of the pandemic. In 2020, drug overdoses caused more deaths among PEH than the next three largest causes of death (coronary heart disease, COVID-19, and traffic injuries) combined.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4b6063e9-2562-4c1d-ac5f-bc0381508be8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4b6063e9-2562-4c1d-ac5f-bc0381508be8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Prepandemic defined as April 1, 2019, to March 31, 2020, and postpandemic defined as April 1, 2020, to March 31, 2021, based on LA County mortality report classifications. Mortality among people experiencing homelessness in Los Angeles County, April 2022; Recent trends in mortality rates and causes of death among people experiencing homelessness in Los Angeles County, Los Angeles County Department of Public Health, January 2021.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>Lack of shelter: Exacerbated health risks</h3>
<p>Some 49,000 people, or 70 percent of PEH in LA County, live without shelter, the largest number in the nation and about eight times that of New York City.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27f12cb3-a953-4844-a033-32dc4a83422d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27f12cb3-a953-4844-a033-32dc4a83422d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Comparison to New York City is based on 2022 HUD point-in-time counts for the New York City continuum of care sheltered emergency shelter homeless (55,677 sheltered out of 61,840 PEH) compared to the Los Angeles City and County continuum of care sheltered emergency shelter homeless (16,287 sheltered out of 65,111 PEH). 2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count, September 8, 2022; “CoC Homeless Populations,” accessed March 20, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Despite the number of shelter beds increasing by 80 percent from 2016 to 2022, today the county has only enough beds to shelter 36 percent of PEH, potentially due to Los Angeles’s historical emphasis on permanent housing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="41826f62-8ab8-4f1b-acb5-dd5939f0f4a1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="41826f62-8ab8-4f1b-acb5-dd5939f0f4a1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">LAHSA includes emergency shelters, transitional housing, and safe havens in its shelter count. “LA CoC shelter count & housing inventory count,” LAHSA, accessed March 7, 2023; 2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count (presentation), LAHSA, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Among other consequences, the lack of shelter increases health-related risks for PEH, as was seen with the breakouts of hepatitis and typhus in 2018 and 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fcd00137-fe7b-416f-a040-dc0be7a5f47f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fcd00137-fe7b-416f-a040-dc0be7a5f47f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anna Gorman and <em>Kaiser Health News</em>, “Medieval diseases are infecting California’s homeless,” <em>The Atlantic</em>, March 8, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> In addition, 84 percent of unsheltered individuals report detrimental physical health conditions, compared with just 19 percent of sheltered individuals.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="eef1aac6-7f60-475c-a44e-f9b732eb9b3f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="eef1aac6-7f60-475c-a44e-f9b732eb9b3f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nathan Hess, Austin Lyke, and Janey Rountree, Health conditions among unsheltered adults in the U.S., California Policy Lab, October 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>A crisis outpacing current solutions</h2>
<p>Major funding increases to the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA), the lead agency in the county’s continuum of care, have risen in parallel with rising homelessness in LA (Exhibit 3). In the 2014–15 financial year, LAHSA received funding of $63 million.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="396d17e2-b696-4801-b5e5-9afa45789d4f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="396d17e2-b696-4801-b5e5-9afa45789d4f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority financial statements and single audit report on expenditures of federal awards: Fiscal Year ended June 30, 2015, LAHSA, March 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> By 2022, funding had increased nearly 13-fold to about $808 million.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fa029c64-1c7c-4538-8c31-46fcdc8618eb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fa029c64-1c7c-4538-8c31-46fcdc8618eb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Kristina M Dixon, FY 2021–22 LAHSA: General fund, roadmap, HHAP updates: Homeless strategy committee presentation, LAHSA, June 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In the same period, the number of PEH in LA County increased by 56 percent.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh3-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Homelessness in Los Angeles has continued to rise in parallel with major funding increases." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh3-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>LAHSA is just one of the major coordinating bodies responsible for allocating funds to address housing and homelessness. In total, LA County receives more than $3 billion<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f1105924-12c9-4cee-a3f4-1f5faf0a9d43"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f1105924-12c9-4cee-a3f4-1f5faf0a9d43" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For the 2021–22 fiscal year, federal funding is estimated at $600 million. State funding is estimated at $1 billion. Mental Health Services Act funding is estimated at $650 million (“MHSA three-year program and expenditure plan,” Los Angeles County Department of Mental Health, June 22, 2021). Measure H funding is estimated at $455 million (“Measure H Citizens’ Oversight Advisory Board meeting agenda,” Los Angeles County, September 2, 2021). Proposition HHH funding is estimated at $362 million (Eric Garcetti, “Proposed budget FY 21-22,” Los Angeles County, April 2021). HUD funding, which is part of federal funding, is based on the 2020–21 fiscal year. “Community Assistance, Recovery & Empowerment Act,” California Health & Human Services Agency, accessed March 7, 2023; Taylor Herhusky, “Major state and federal housing and homelessness funding by California county,” California Health & Human Services Agency, December 23, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> in funding for housing and homelessness across many different programs and uses.</p>
<h3>Current housing-focused efforts are challenged by timing and costs</h3>
<p>Increasing the stock of affordable housing could slow the growth in homelessness, as fewer people would be at risk of falling into homelessness and more people would be capable of resolving out of it if housing costs accounted for a smaller proportion of their earnings.</p>
<p>Many efforts to increase affordable housing are under way in LA, yet a severe shortage of affordable housing will remain for decades, given the current rate of construction. Although a sizable amount of funding has gone into attempts to build affordable housing units,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a2be9519-55d9-4677-b9a6-316eaafac219"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a2be9519-55d9-4677-b9a6-316eaafac219" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Affordable housing efforts include Proposition HHH efforts, Homeless Initiative permanent housing, LAHSA permanent housing, and Los Angeles County Development Authority housing development efforts (approximately one-third of total funding, although there may be overlap between coordinating bodies).</span></span></span></a></span> the California Housing Partnership estimates that there is currently a shortage of roughly 500,000 affordable housing units for LA County’s 800,000 low-income and extremely low-income residents.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="61186d5b-28b2-445c-a3a8-df8508a9b316"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="61186d5b-28b2-445c-a3a8-df8508a9b316" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Danielle M Mazzella and Lindsay Rosenfeld, Los Angeles County housing need report 2021, California Housing Partnership, May 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, as explained in <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/affordable-housing-in-los-angeles-delivering-more-and-doing-it-faster">Affordable housing in Los Angeles: Delivering more—and doing it faster</a>, at the current pace of construction, it would take more than 35 years to achieve this goal, rather than the eight years mandated in the state Regional Housing Needs Assessment, at an estimated cost of about $134 billion.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e74e96be-f7ad-48b7-b60d-def20f29b63b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e74e96be-f7ad-48b7-b60d-def20f29b63b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/affordable-housing-in-los-angeles-delivering-more-and-doing-it-faster">Affordable housing in Los Angeles: Delivering more—and doing it faster</a></em>, McKinsey, November 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>This current challenge largely stems from a long-standing affordable housing shortage. Between 2014 and 2018, fewer than one in ten new units permitted by LA County were classified as affordable, defined as consuming less than 30 percent of the occupant’s monthly household income.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="adff7dbe-aee4-4033-b783-9d024478c949"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="adff7dbe-aee4-4033-b783-9d024478c949" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/affordable-housing-in-los-angeles-delivering-more-and-doing-it-faster">Affordable housing in Los Angeles: Delivering more—and doing it faster</a></em>, McKinsey, November 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> Part of this shortage is attributable to the complexity of the approval process: preconstruction time for an affordable project in LA may be 52 months, compared with 30 months for market-rate housing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fd2fa0f8-f3cd-4983-9ec7-5d19131f983e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fd2fa0f8-f3cd-4983-9ec7-5d19131f983e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Analysis is based on developers in the LA region. This article considers affordable housing to be rent or payment less than 30 percent of household income, a benchmark used by the World Bank and the US Department of Housing and Urban Development. <em><a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/affordable-housing-in-los-angeles-delivering-more-and-doing-it-faster">Affordable housing in Los Angeles: Delivering more—and doing it faster</a></em>, November 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> Construction is also expensive, averaging more than $550,000 per unit.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2a335f7c-d622-460b-a1ab-5254f6b62bb8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2a335f7c-d622-460b-a1ab-5254f6b62bb8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ron Galperin, The problems and progress of Prop. HHH, City of Los Angeles Controller’s Office, February 23, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>In 2016, a $1.2 billion bond, Proposition HHH, was passed to build housing. Since then, just over 2,250 units have been built—or 23 percent of Proposition HHH’s ten-year goal. Under the Mental Health Services Act, about 1,100 affordable housing units have been leased or occupied since 2008, with only 43 of 140 funded projects being completed based on latest publications. Finally, through Measure H, LA has placed 34,000 individuals into permanent housing since 2017—about 76 percent of its 45,000 goal.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f3a99c4-51f7-43d5-b432-d3f9383b22cb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f3a99c4-51f7-43d5-b432-d3f9383b22cb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For a complete list of accomplishments to date on Proposition HHH, Measure H, and the MHSA, see “HHH progress dashboard,” Los Angeles Housing Department, March 3, 2023; “Homeless Initiative impact dashboard,” The Los Angeles Homeless Initiative, accessed March 13, 2023; and MHSA three-year program and expenditure plan: Fiscal years 2021-22 through 2023-24, Los Angeles County Department of Mental Health, June 22, 2021. The numbers in this article for Proposition HHH and Measure H are based on the status of live progress dashboards accessed on March 1, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> To put this in perspective, if LA achieved all Proposition HHH and Measure H goals in 2023, the county could add 7,750 affordable housing units and 11,000 permanent placements. Yet LA would still lack about 492,000 affordable units, and chronically homeless individuals could still be without permanent supportive housing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="af6496da-6667-48fe-8f83-7ee0277b7f08"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="af6496da-6667-48fe-8f83-7ee0277b7f08" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count (presentation), September 8, 2022; “HHH progress dashboard,” Los Angeles Housing Department, March 3, 2023; “MHSA county performance outcomes,” California Department of Health Care Services, updated January 26, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>At its current building rate, LA will not meet its affordable housing needs and will likely need to supplement housing efforts with other initiatives to resolve homelessness. Indeed, in a <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/affordable-housing-in-los-angeles-delivering-more-and-doing-it-faster">McKinsey report on affordable housing in LA</a>, we identified highly underutilized residential parcels that could yield 1.5 million to 1.9 million residential units.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ff27e6b9-8bd6-485f-8382-0f1c84dd3099"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ff27e6b9-8bd6-485f-8382-0f1c84dd3099" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em><a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/affordable-housing-in-los-angeles-delivering-more-and-doing-it-faster">Affordable housing in Los Angeles: Delivering more—and doing it faster</a></em>, McKinsey, November 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>System complexity and structural impediments: Impaired efficiency and effectiveness</h3>
<p>The ability to enact far-reaching and innovative solutions to homelessness in LA County may be complicated by a support ecosystem that is unique in its number of service providers and contracts, its distributed decision-making authority, and its high turnover of employees. This fragmented ecosystem requires coordination across many organizations, with LAHSA, the lead agency in the county’s continuum of care, alone executing more than 1,000 contracts with more than 100 nonprofits each year.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="168c01f7-7da9-42ad-80df-6b75447a3dc1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="168c01f7-7da9-42ad-80df-6b75447a3dc1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“LAHSA FY 2022–2023 budget,” LAHSA, January 31, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> By comparison, the New York City Department of Homeless Services (DHS) manages 517 active contracts with a similar PEH population (Exhibit 4).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh4-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority manages about twice as many contracts as its New York counterpart for a similar number of people." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh4-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>LA has no county department exclusively responsible for homelessness, with responsibilities and decision making dispersed across various agencies, the county, and individual cities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="052562f0-c575-4032-a089-b95ecedcecd0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="052562f0-c575-4032-a089-b95ecedcecd0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Blue Ribbon Commission on Homelessness governance report,” Blue Ribbon Commission on Homelessness, March 30, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The homelessness services field in LA also experiences staff turnover, vacancies, and delays in recruiting and hiring, resulting in a lack of frontline workers to support the increasing PEH population. For example, PATH, a nonprofit that serves about a fifth of California’s homeless population, hired seven recruiters to help fill 340 vacancies—and the average lead time to fill one was four months.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="88c90c11-cd57-478c-8559-5a3e7861f49d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="88c90c11-cd57-478c-8559-5a3e7861f49d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Manuela Tobias, “Will worker shortage disrupt California homeless strategy?” CalMatters, January 27, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> This shortage of workers can be partially attributed to low wages, with most frontline workers making between $16 and $18 an hour, barely higher than minimum wage.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1f1ac662-bbb4-4028-b2ef-85424c6d8693"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1f1ac662-bbb4-4028-b2ef-85424c6d8693" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Manuela Tobias, “Will worker shortage disrupt California homeless strategy?” CalMatters, January 27, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> In fact, in March 2021 LAHSA increased base pay for its employees to $50,000 a year from $33,119 after learning some of its own employees were experiencing homelessness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7017b03a-183a-4b41-ac07-7727616cf380"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7017b03a-183a-4b41-ac07-7727616cf380" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Heidi Marston, “The homelessness crisis: A monster of our own making,” Medium, April 25, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h2>Developing LA-focused solutions</h2>
<p>The homelessness crisis in LA is worsening. And because of its unique nature, it is unlikely to be resolved through traditional approaches utilized in other communities alone. In particular, building more housing is not enough on its own. Given the scale and complexity of the crisis, any solution may need tailored, large-scale coordination, the likes of which are typically seen in national-scale emergencies.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a55652d4-810b-43d2-8bf4-9a6ca09baa60"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a55652d4-810b-43d2-8bf4-9a6ca09baa60" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For example, FEMA uses a National Disaster Recovery Framework (NDRF) as a guide to promote effective recovery for incidents that are large-scale or catastrophic. National Disaster Recovery Framework: Strengthening disaster recovery for the nation, Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA), September 2011.</span></span></span></a></span> In the face of this complexity, LA could adopt a journey- and fact-based approach to solving homelessness. While the public sector would naturally lead these efforts, the private sector also has a role to play.</p>
<h3>Adopting journey-based solutions</h3>
<p>Individual experiences with homelessness can be considered across two dimensions: the stage of homelessness and the circumstances that led to homelessness. The progression into homelessness starts with one being at-risk, often due to economic factors. The next stage is being nonchronically homeless—that is, less than one year without housing. This stage is followed by being chronically homeless, where one has been homeless for more than a year or has had multiple episodes over several years.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right"
