class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Who is experiencing homelessness?</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>LA County’s population of people experiencing homelessness spans factors including gender, age, and race (exhibit), and the background of individuals also varies. The journey to homelessness is not caused by a single factor, nor is it linear, with contributing factors often intertwined with peoples’ backgrounds and a broader historical and societal context.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh-sidebar-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The homeless population of Los Angeles spans demographics." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/public%20and%20social%20sector/our%20insights/homelessness%20in%20los%20angeles%20a%20unique%20crisis%20demanding%20new%20solutions/svgz-homelessness-in-la-exh-sidebar-vf.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>A 2020 Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) survey of 4,304 people newly experiencing homelessness in the city found that the top five factors cited were economic hardship, weakened social networks, disabling health conditions, system discharge (for example, from prison or foster care), and flight from violence.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f1e66873-e59c-41cb-af09-c4c08ab487b3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f1e66873-e59c-41cb-af09-c4c08ab487b3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Greater Los Angeles homeless count 2020, LAHSA, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Contrary to popular myth, the majority of PEH in LA are not coming from other regions: 74 percent of unsheltered individuals lived in Southern California before becoming homeless, and 71 percent have been in LA County for more than ten years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e71635ce-068f-4b2d-a83a-32dc9e84a69b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e71635ce-068f-4b2d-a83a-32dc9e84a69b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">As of 2020; Greater Los Angeles homeless count 2020, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Some 42,000 PEH, or 60 percent, are located in the City of LA, with the highest concentrations in southeast neighborhoods.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="215f1a25-f283-4852-908e-64fb8f17d8d0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="215f1a25-f283-4852-908e-64fb8f17d8d0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count, presentation, LAHSA, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Women comprise almost a third of the LA homeless population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b73aeb73-27ae-4006-91df-87e1328df8f9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b73aeb73-27ae-4006-91df-87e1328df8f9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count data summary, LAHSA, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> While 8 percent of total PEH in LA report being homeless due to fleeing domestic violence, that number masks a more troubling reality. Domestic violence disproportionately affects the more than 22,000 women experiencing homelessness, with nearly 50 percent of all unsheltered women in LA reporting a lifetime history of domestic and sexual violence.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6dcf70c5-641c-4a2e-a54c-72903914b593"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6dcf70c5-641c-4a2e-a54c-72903914b593" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Annual Greater Los Angeles homeless count, Downtown Women’s Center, accessed March 7, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Some 30 percent of the LA homeless population is Black<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6502837a-0405-493e-9ecd-792005b0fce8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6502837a-0405-493e-9ecd-792005b0fce8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count, presentation, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span>—or 3.3 times the rate of the overall population. The homelessness rates for all other ethnicities are lower than their share of the general population.</p>
<p>Veterans also experience homelessness at higher rates. Roughly 6 percent of people experiencing homelessness are veterans, 2.3 times the rate of the overall population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="96570368-03c3-4139-9457-86048c800202"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="96570368-03c3-4139-9457-86048c800202" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count data summary, September 8, 2022; “QuickFacts: Los Angeles County, California: People with a disability, under age 65 years, percent, 2017–2021,” US Census Bureau, July 21, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> Lastly, about 30 percent of PEH in LA County are sheltered, and 40 percent are considered chronically homeless.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="03a3176b-7db4-4e5e-9fe7-faf9345ac1e7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="03a3176b-7db4-4e5e-9fe7-faf9345ac1e7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count, presentation, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>At-risk individuals, the nonchronically homeless, and the chronically homeless need different interventions—for example, the nonchronically homeless may need support with career placement, while people experiencing chronic homelessness may first need help with a substance use disorder or mental health issues. Similarly, the pathway that led to homelessness suggests different interventions. For example, survivors of domestic violence may require different types of support than the formerly incarcerated. Adopting journey-based solutions may help address the root causes of homelessness and ensure people receive sufficient support depending on their individual needs. In addition, this approach allows efforts to account for the fact the city’s homeless population is far from homogeneous (see sidebar, “Who is experiencing homelessness?”) and, while disproportionately composed of vulnerable populations, is largely composed of individuals from or already living in the region.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8b18751d-9c88-4de2-b34e-1f2117a5c7fa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8b18751d-9c88-4de2-b34e-1f2117a5c7fa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Greater Los Angeles homeless count 2020, LAHSA, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>Prevention efforts may help reduce those at risk of homelessness</h4>
<p>Nearly 600,000 households are severely rent burdened in LA, placing them at risk of homelessness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ddd8f95c-4712-4291-bcdd-7a2486659eac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ddd8f95c-4712-4291-bcdd-7a2486659eac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">HUD defines severe rent burden as paying more than 50 percent of one’s income on rent. HUD defines individuals and families at risk for homelessness as those: i) with annual income below 30 percent median family income for area; ii) who do not have sufficient resources to prevent moving to emergency shelter; iii) who meet an additional condition including a) having moved for economic reasons twice during the previous 60 days, b) living in another’s home due to economic hardship, c) having been notified of potential eviction within 21 days, d) living in a hotel paid for by a charitable or government organization, e) living in a single-room-occupancy (SRO)/efficiency apartment with more than two others, f) exiting a publicly funded institution, g) living in unstable housing. LAHSA determines homeless inflows and outflows by considering severely rent-burdened LA households as potentially at risk for homelessness. “Rental burdens: Rethinking affordability measures,” <em>PD&R Edge</em>, HUD Office of Policy Development and Research, September 22, 2014; “At risk of homelessness,” HUD, accessed March 7, 2023; Greater Los Angeles homeless count 2020, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> This level of rent burden has increased over time as incomes in LA have been unable to keep pace with high housing prices and rents: from 2010 to 2019, average rents in LA increased by 65 percent, while household incomes rose only 36 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f0ad134-fe29-4718-a14c-7d6774ac50a2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f0ad134-fe29-4718-a14c-7d6774ac50a2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jack Flemming, “L.A. rent rose 65% over the last decade, study shows,” <em>Los Angeles Times</em>, December 27, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While populations at risk of homelessness undoubtedly need affordable, secure housing, other forms of assistance may also play a role in preventing homelessness. For example, connecting at-risk populations to CalFresh or Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) programs could free up money normally spent on food to be used for rent or other necessities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9021d826-2d17-464f-9970-42bfdfee78fb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">46</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9021d826-2d17-464f-9970-42bfdfee78fb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Anna Gorman and Harriet Blair Rowan, “‘A persistent puzzle’: Californians embrace Medicaid—but food stamps? Not so much,” <em>Kaiser Health News</em>, May 2, 2018.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, during the pandemic, rates of homelessness temporarily decreased in parallel with the significant amounts of financial aid disbursed.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6fd08232-7267-4629-bdf1-0ace9ed8b578"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">47</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6fd08232-7267-4629-bdf1-0ace9ed8b578" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Patrick Burns, “Breaking the fall: Successful homeless interventions in the COVID pandemic,” Economic Roundtable, December 15, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Like most cities and counties, LA prioritizes individuals for support and housing based on criticality of need, usually those who are chronically homeless with a history of mental health challenges or other vulnerabilities.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="18938f0c-6b2a-493b-8efd-d2df0501e64f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">48</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="18938f0c-6b2a-493b-8efd-d2df0501e64f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">LA uses a points-based self-reporting tool called Vulnerability Index—Service Prioritization Decision Assistance Tool (VI–SPDAT) to prioritize care for those in need. A person who is experiencing homelessness for the first time and living out of their car might score lower on this scale than someone with chronic physical conditions and drug addiction sleeping in a sleeping bag on the sidewalk.</span></span></span></a></span> As a result, at-risk populations are often provided fewer resources and interventions. For example, just 3.6 percent of LA County’s 2022–23 homelessness spending plan, or $18.9 million, is allocated to prevention measures.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a96364bc-99f7-4886-b093-96e286bb604d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">49</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a96364bc-99f7-4886-b093-96e286bb604d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“$532.6M Homeless Initiative spending plan for FY 2022–23,” Los Angeles County Homeless Initiative, May 17, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Providing additional funding to prevention efforts could be cost-effective; research has indicated that actions focused on prevention may help reduce housing insecurity.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b966b2e5-14b0-4880-9e4e-408e7a6343aa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">50</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b966b2e5-14b0-4880-9e4e-408e7a6343aa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sanmay Das et al., “Solving homelessness from a complex systems perspective: Insights for prevention responses,” <em>Annual Review of Public Health</em>, 2019, Volume 40.</span></span></span></a></span> LA County is already piloting a predictive tool developed by UCLA researchers at the California Policy Lab to help identify and assist those at greatest risk of losing their homes.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="03c5a1df-2691-484f-89e1-b8d2e9b4a94e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">51</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="03c5a1df-2691-484f-89e1-b8d2e9b4a94e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ariel Wesler, “LA County uses computer model to help predict homelessness,” <em>Spectrum News</em>, July 14, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>Rapid support for nonchronically homeless individuals</h4>
<p>The nonchronically homeless in LA total approximately 41,000 people, or about 60 percent of the PEH population.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9bd785a4-a7fa-42f8-b3a5-c453805a085d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">52</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9bd785a4-a7fa-42f8-b3a5-c453805a085d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count data summary, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> These individuals are more often able to “self resolve,” or exit from homelessness with less intensive support than the chronically homeless.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1c0cf210-a8a0-49a6-9d00-6d673dff132b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">53</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1c0cf210-a8a0-49a6-9d00-6d673dff132b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2020 Greater Los Angeles homeless count results, LAHSA, September 3, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In fact, a 2020 LAHSA report says that out of all exits from homelessness, 70 percent were through self-resolution.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2d1ef2de-b958-456b-9755-e8c34cc9fa44"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">54</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2d1ef2de-b958-456b-9755-e8c34cc9fa44" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Based on 2020 Greater Los Angeles homeless count; 2020 Greater Los Angeles homeless count results, September 3, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> For those who may need additional support to return to housing, there are smaller, meaningful interventions that could help beyond building affordable housing stock. For instance, case management—coupled with housing vouchers and other financial forms of assistance—has been found to successfully place nonchronically homeless populations into housing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dd0200fc-1e99-4c82-93ac-3bf731030536"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">55</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dd0200fc-1e99-4c82-93ac-3bf731030536" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Using tenant-based housing vouchers to help end homelessness in Los Angeles, 2016–2020, Abt Associates, July 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Interventions are typically more effective when quickly provided to newly homeless individuals. The longer the nonchronically homeless wait for housing or other forms of support, the more likely they are to be driven into chronic homelessness, which is associated with worsened health conditions and a lower propensity to resolve out of homelessness and requires more complex solutions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5b857272-e657-462b-938a-eda446507f71"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">56</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5b857272-e657-462b-938a-eda446507f71" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Erin Bagalman and Libby Perl, Chronic homelessness: Background, research, and outcomes, Congressional Research Service, December 8, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While temporary housing in shelters can be a common form of support for the nonchronically homeless, not enough exist today to meet the needs of the unsheltered homeless population. As previously mentioned, the county today has enough beds to shelter only 36 percent of PEH.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b0b86c25-2749-4dba-9e4e-7501fe237baf"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">57</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b0b86c25-2749-4dba-9e4e-7501fe237baf" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">LAHSA includes emergency shelters, transitional housing and safe havens in its shelter count. “LA CoC shelter count & housing inventory count (HIC),” LAHSA, accessed March 7, 2023; 2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count (presentation), September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> However, simply building more shelters may not be enough; studies suggest shelters are not a one-size-fits-all solution. For example, PEH often cite privacy and safety concerns as top decision factors when choosing to accept housing support.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d12181ab-0da0-4e99-8a65-ce5bcb6a0eea"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">58</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d12181ab-0da0-4e99-8a65-ce5bcb6a0eea" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Rick Garvey, Sarah B Hunter, and Jason M Ward, “Recent trends among the unsheltered in three Los Angeles neighborhoods,” RAND Corporation, May 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Survivors of domestic abuse, LGBTQ+ individuals, and people with disabilities who find themselves homeless may have different privacy and safety needs when it comes to shelters.</p>
<h4>Tailored support services for the chronically homeless</h4>
<p>As a society, we cannot give up on those unlikely to self-resolve out of homelessness due to substance use disorders, mental illness, or other disabilities. Without support, individuals may continue cycling in and out of homelessness for years on end—leaving a sizable segment of Angelenos struggling to build and lead quality lives. We need to find ways to systematically ensure that the chronically homeless get the care that they need.</p>
<p>Historically, interpretation of the Martin v. City of Boise ruling limited the city’s ability to effectively render care to the chronically homeless.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="604fa7eb-aa1a-4ebf-bfe1-6f8cce1c7f57"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">59</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="604fa7eb-aa1a-4ebf-bfe1-6f8cce1c7f57" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In Martin v. Boise, the US Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that homeless individuals cannot be punished for sleeping outdoors in public spaces when there are not sufficient alternatives available for housing. “Martin v. City of Boise: Ninth Circuit refuses to reconsider invalidation of ordinances completely banning sleeping and camping in public,” <em>Harvard Law Review</em>, December 2019, Volume 133, Number 2.</span></span></span></a></span> While the long-term effects are still to be determined, new initiatives are being introduced, including directive care for those in psychiatric crisis in New York City and the Community, Assistance, Recovery, and Empowerment (CARE) Court in the state of California; these may offer potential pathways to breaking this deadlock.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f59cb94b-7aac-4368-990c-c47a40f2790d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">60</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f59cb94b-7aac-4368-990c-c47a40f2790d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Mayor Adams announces plan to provide care for individuals suffering from untreated severe mental illness across NYC,” City of New York, November 29, 2022; “Governor Newsom and counties begin CARE Court implementation,” State of California, December 1, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> Even so, there are no at-scale long-term comprehensive solutions for the chronically homeless, whose need for mental health and substance use disorder treatment is as important as their need for housing. A 2018 report by the California Hospital Association indicates a need for more than 2,500 additional mental health beds in LA County.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f8d04d7c-8864-43ca-ae0b-08f6d9257cab"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">61</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f8d04d7c-8864-43ca-ae0b-08f6d9257cab" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">California psychiatric bed annual report, California Hospital Association, August 2018.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>While housing is just part of the solution, permanent supportive housing, for example, has been shown to successfully house individuals experiencing chronic homelessness, with 86 percent of individuals placed remaining in housing for several years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dcda78a4-fadf-4380-a3f7-c868567b0417"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">62</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dcda78a4-fadf-4380-a3f7-c868567b0417" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">HUD defines permanent supportive housing (PSH) as permanent housing in which housing assistance (for example, long-term leasing or rental assistance) and supportive services are provided to assist households with at least one member (adult or child) with a disability in achieving housing stability. “Permanent Supportive Housing (PSH),” HUD Exchange, HUD, accessed March 20, 2023; Laura Kurtzman, “Study finds permanent supportive housing is effective for highest risk chronically homeless people,” University of California, San Francisco, September 17, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In Houston, officials were able to significantly decrease chronic homelessness—in a much smaller population of homeless individuals than in Los Angeles—by prioritizing rapid placement of the chronically homeless directly into apartments with supportive wraparound services, rather than first placing them into shelters.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4ae0cf19-ffeb-44db-82ee-fb750c72608e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">63</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4ae0cf19-ffeb-44db-82ee-fb750c72608e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Michael Kimmelman and Lucy Tompkins, “How Houston moved 25,000 people from the streets into homes of their own,” <em>New York Times</em>, February 13, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>As such, housing alone is just part of the solution. Given the numerous challenges faced by the chronically homeless, service providers could meet them where they are to help them better access existing services. For example, more could be done to coordinate and widen the range of services provided for chronically homeless individuals who are also experiencing severe mental illness, substance use disorders, or physical disabilities. Louisiana Chronically Homeless Assistance and Treatment Services (LaCHATS), for instance, set up a One-Stop Homeless Services Center, bringing together a coalition of 35 service providers across mental healthcare, legal services, and employment assistance as well as permanent supportive housing under one roof.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8b6c3162-bb3c-4043-b983-2a808a42aa21"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">64</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8b6c3162-bb3c-4043-b983-2a808a42aa21" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“LaCHATS project One-Stop Homeless Services Center,” US Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, April 30, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> These methods are effective but resource-intensive, further underscoring the importance of also focusing on prevention measures before people enter chronic homelessness.</p>
<h3>The role of business: Three ways companies can lead</h3>
<p>The private sector accounts for just under 88 percent of employment in LA County and is both crucial and well positioned to support PEH and drive sustainable and inclusive growth.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f8c27a5b-3827-4c90-b5b4-73892f2c69ce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">65</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f8c27a5b-3827-4c90-b5b4-73892f2c69ce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Quarterly census of employment and wages (QCEW)—Los Angeles County,” US Bureau of Labor Statistics and California Employment Development Department, December 9, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> With the vast majority of PEH having held prior employment, each business has a unique opportunity to both assist and support PEH as well as actively engage in preventing further individuals from experiencing homelessness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="42158f52-e9f3-43e8-8231-2608983653eb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">66</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="42158f52-e9f3-43e8-8231-2608983653eb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Nefara Riesch, Geoffrey Schnorr, and Till von Wachter, “Employment among LA County residents experiencing homelessness,” California Policy Lab, February 26, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Indeed, without the private sector’s active involvement, there is little chance of delivering an effective response to the current crisis.</p>
<p>No single organization has the ability to address this crisis on its own, and efforts undertaken by the private sector are in no way a substitute for the public sector’s role or responsibility in solving homelessness. But if businesses could unlock their collective strength and resources, they could be able to make a meaningful impact on LA’s homelessness crisis, ultimately making LA a place that works better for all Angelenos. There are three potential but not all-encompassing actions for companies considering starting on this path.</p>
<h4>Resourcing: Supporting at-risk employees</h4>
<p>Employers can play a crucial role in supporting at-risk individuals, starting by understanding their own employee base. With data and proximity to their workforce, employers may be best suited to connect employees at risk of homelessness with appropriate resources, such as social safety net programs and housing search and placement services. Employers can also conduct anonymous company-wide surveys to understand the needs of at-risk populations and help connect their workforces with the most helpful supportive services, such as housing assistance, counseling, and personal financial planning (and provide hotlines for employees to anonymously connect with them).</p>
<p>Nearly 600,000 households in LA are severely rent burdened today,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c3ee2bba-6b7e-48b2-af2d-d8e4e19b0b59"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">67</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c3ee2bba-6b7e-48b2-af2d-d8e4e19b0b59" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Greater Los Angeles homeless count 2020, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> and more than 100,000 households could be at risk of eviction.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f9366750-19c0-44ce-8813-3eda7668d6b3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">68</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f9366750-19c0-44ce-8813-3eda7668d6b3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Les Dunseith, “New study warns of looming eviction crisis in Los Angeles County,” University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) Luskin School of Public Affairs, May 28, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span>  Yet, in 2017, LA County indicated an uptake rate of CalFresh benefits of 66.3 percent, placing LA in the bottom third relative to other counties in California.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e6728b82-e55a-4e72-a43d-47ab798a6dbd"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">69</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e6728b82-e55a-4e72-a43d-47ab798a6dbd" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Motion by Supervisors Sheila Kuehl and Janice Hahn: Reduce prevalence of food insecurity and poverty by increasing CalFresh participation,” Los Angeles County, May 23, 2017.</span></span></span></a></span> Employers have a unique opportunity to directly affect their employees and the communities around them and ultimately reduce the incidence of homelessness.</p>
<p>First, private-sector organizations could commit to understanding their workforce and its relationship to homelessness through topics like employee financial health, the risk of experiencing homelessness, and previous episodes of homelessness. Once companies learn about the needs of at-risk or already homeless employees, they could then offer an internal, anonymous, highly accessible, one-stop shop to connect employees to social safety net programs or effective in-house resources. We found 78 percent of employees who have previously experienced homelessness would find value in streamlined employer information and assistance to navigate social services—13 percentage points more than other employees. Likewise, 79 percent would find employer assistance to navigate health insurance valuable—nine percentage points more than other employees.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="86ef5232-14ea-468b-84b6-c6d7c26cc124"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">70</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="86ef5232-14ea-468b-84b6-c6d7c26cc124" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey survey of LA County adults (n = 1,004, September 2022).</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Second, in-house resources could be far-reaching. Employers could offer flexible working arrangements, such as time off or remote work, to support individuals who may need to attend housing appointments or accommodation hearings. These employees may also benefit from resources such as workplace attire and transportation to and from work (for example, public-transit credits), both of which may act as cost barriers for the financially burdened. Housing search and placement services, shared housing, free access to a gym or shower, and temporary hotel rooms could help support employees faster than a social service provider.</p>
<p>Third, many of these benefits may help the workforce broadly and even minimize employers’ turnover costs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ba157d8d-4b19-471d-b213-5e9de1938956"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">71</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ba157d8d-4b19-471d-b213-5e9de1938956" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Shane McFeely and Ben Wigert, “This fixable problem costs U.S. businesses $1 trillion,” Gallup, March 13, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> According to the US Department of Labor, employers save up to $16 for every dollar invested in an employee assistance plan.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="98089c82-8031-4fde-aee5-75253e52a53e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">72</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="98089c82-8031-4fde-aee5-75253e52a53e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Business case for EAPs: Employee Assistance Program Fact Sheet,” US Office of Personnel Management, accessed March 20, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Offering these forms of support not only could give at-risk individuals a needed reprieve that offers them time to stabilize their situation but also could attract and retain the best talent.</p>
<h4>Reconfiguring: Diversifying talent pipelines to create employment opportunities for more Angelenos</h4>
<p>All employers can partner with workforce development organizations (such as educational systems and nonprofits) to share requirements for job opportunities and to raise awareness of opportunities for employment for groups such as survivors of domestic abuse and those aging out of foster care. This can enable at-risk and homeless individuals to learn valuable skills and find gainful employment.</p>
<p>With an average of roughly 435,000 unique job openings posted per quarter in 2022, underemployment today appears to be driven by a skills mismatch in the economy, not a lack of jobs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b0db2e4d-e66d-4ba5-a844-2019404833b3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">73</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b0db2e4d-e66d-4ba5-a844-2019404833b3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lightcast average quarterly job postings from 2022 by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) sector, accessed January 15, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> With lack of skills reported as the number-one barrier to finding a job in LA,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="13568ad5-6a96-4364-a1c9-bf92e5c9cd9c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">74</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="13568ad5-6a96-4364-a1c9-bf92e5c9cd9c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey American Opportunity Survey 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> developing stronger alignment between the skills the population possesses and the talent needs of the private sector could support numerous Angelenos looking for employment, particularly the nearly 600,000 members of severely rent-burdened households<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c48af5d1-ca34-4473-80f1-a58f2aec8d25"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">75</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c48af5d1-ca34-4473-80f1-a58f2aec8d25" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Greater Los Angeles homeless count 2020, June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> and the 69,000 individuals currently experiencing homelessness.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c831eb1d-80a0-4dd1-98d5-c6634058fec7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">76</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c831eb1d-80a0-4dd1-98d5-c6634058fec7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">2022 Greater Los Angeles homeless count—Los Angeles County, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> That could help reduce the financial difficulties that prevent many people from directly paying for housing and affect their ability to obtain healthcare, education, and other necessities.</p>
<p>Employers can take a two-pronged approach to better align available talent with skills needed. First, they can assess recruiting requirements and adopt skills-based hiring where possible.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9f7576ee-3adc-4dd4-ba5e-d5d603908209"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">77</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9f7576ee-3adc-4dd4-ba5e-d5d603908209" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Joseph Fuller, Christina Langer, and Matt Sigelman, “Skills-based hiring is on the rise,” Harvard Business Review, February 11, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> They can be clear about required versus preferred competencies for each role and can enable the at-risk population and PEH with certain skills to qualify for employment, ultimately screening them in rather than out of open job opportunities.</p>
<p>A common misconception is that those experiencing homelessness are not employed or do not want to be employed.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6a09825b-764e-4c2e-b509-67fca5536da9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">78</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6a09825b-764e-4c2e-b509-67fca5536da9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Robert Polner, “The 12 biggest myths about homelessness in America,” New York University (NYU), September 24, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> Within its multiyear LA County study of 137,000 homeless clients, of whom 74 percent were employed prior to their first enrollment in homelessness support services, the California Policy Lab found that 65 percent of clients employed before enrolling in services worked in several major job categories before obtaining services.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f936d242-7965-4e2d-8059-aaea17010d03"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">79</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f936d242-7965-4e2d-8059-aaea17010d03" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">These categories included administrative support, waste management, and remediation services (28 percent); healthcare and social assistance (14 percent); accommodation and food services (12 percent); and retail (11 percent); “Employment and earnings among LA County residents experiencing homelessness,” February 26, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> Skills-based hiring can potentially allow for more PEH to access employment, reintegrating those not currently in the workforce and becoming a major driver of return to stability. Employers can receive financial supports as well. California recently passed a Homeless Hiring Tax Credit, providing tax credits of up to $30,000 to each employer who hires current or recently homeless individuals (for example, youth aging out of foster care).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9bed7234-3480-4b78-a2df-25feaa16aff9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">80</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9bed7234-3480-4b78-a2df-25feaa16aff9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Credits range from $2,500 to $10,000 per employee hired. “Homeless Hiring Tax Credit: Assembly Bill (AB) 150,” California Franchise Tax Board, December 20, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Second, employers could invest in the skills needed for their prospective and current employees to progress into new roles and opportunities by offering upskilling opportunities such as training programs and apprenticeships, partnering with educational systems and nonprofits to develop a talent pipeline for at-risk communities. Such programs can improve workforce retention for employers and provide employment stability to employees.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7e731cf1-6dde-4547-a285-f3aa5c69882f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">81</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7e731cf1-6dde-4547-a285-f3aa5c69882f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey survey of LA County adults (n = 1,004, September 2022). McKinsey conducted a survey of employees of small and large businesses in LA County to understand their experiences with the homelessness crisis in the region.</span></span></span></a></span> Given the high number of entry-level openings and unfilled roles, the private sector can create pathways for at-risk Angelenos to develop specific skill sets required for jobs and commit to recruiting those who have established those skills (for example, through online learning and on-the-job learning). Such programs improve workforce retention and are also cost-effective: on average, it costs $24,000 to reskill an employee, while the cost of replacing an individual employee can be up to double that employee’s salary.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="59fdedac-8d72-4bcb-8164-e1d4b87a3b4f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">82</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="59fdedac-8d72-4bcb-8164-e1d4b87a3b4f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Briony Harris, “Who should pay for workers to be reskilled?,” World Economic Forum, January 22, 2019; “This fixable problem costs U.S. businesses $1 trillion,” March 13, 2019.</span></span></span></a></span> Many companies have already participated in successful efforts to either hire or upskill at-risk communities by partnering with nonprofit organizations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ab006d4a-e5ee-4b38-8328-be428a80d991"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">83</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ab006d4a-e5ee-4b38-8328-be428a80d991" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Chrysalis is a nonprofit organization in LA that helps individuals navigate barriers to the workforce through a job readiness program. In 2021, Chrysalis helped 1,553 individuals obtain employment and employed 1,611 individuals in transitional employment. Social Finance is a national impact finance and advisory nonprofit that works with the public, private, and social sectors to build innovative partnerships and investments that measurably improve lives. “Forging new roads: A year in review: 2021 executive summary,” Chrysalis, July 27, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>Reimagining: Supporting capabilities and talent</h4>
<p>Countless organizations and individuals are dedicated to improving the lives of people experiencing homelessness. As discussed above, the impact of these efforts can be diminished by the fragmented ecosystem of organizations, complex governance structures, and operational and talent management challenges. Even more importantly, no robust, comparable, outcomes-based data or performance metrics exist, making it impossible to determine what programs are effective. Efforts to create such systems are hampered by lack of funding and technical expertise. To help overcome these challenges, employers could partner with nonprofits to build capabilities by offering secondments and externships, sharing technology infrastructure and analytics tools, and implementing best practices to enhance innovation in the nonprofit sphere.</p>
<p>By working out an approach to collecting, analyzing, and using data, the private sector could support LA’s leaders in developing and tracking key performance indicators across the county’s hundreds of service providers. Not only would such an approach help to identify organizations and solutions with proven impact, but it could result in better resource allocation toward the right set of solutions. Leveraging data can also help leaders make faster decisions on which solutions to test, pilot, and ultimately scale, bringing a whole new level of speed and agility to the public sector’s efforts.</p>
<p>Similarly, there is an opportunity to eliminate challenges that prevent institutions administering aid from becoming more effective and sustainable. For example, a new public–private partnership could create a flagship LA center of excellence for homelessness services to drive a new era of operational excellence among all stakeholders. Such a center could vastly improve access to best-in-class capability building. In partnership with public- and social-sector organizations, it could be supported by experienced leaders from the private sector and offer programs across topics such as contract management, human resources management, and technology management. This center could even offer shared resources for smaller nonprofits—for example, taking existing centralized recruiting and proactively matching job seekers to homelessness service providers. Such a partnership could allow all stakeholders in the homelessness ecosystem to align on goals and approaches while gaining equal access to resources to unlock their full potential.</p>
<p>Additionally, the private sector could adopt specific priorities within or in parallel to the center of excellence. Many nonprofits today seek technology infrastructure and tools considered basic requirements in many private-sector organizations. Nonprofits are limited by a lack of computers, poor internet access, and outdated software products. Prioritizing technology-enabled coordination could help nonprofits successfully transform their operating models, while the adoption of new software could amplify efforts to share data and reporting platforms to harmonize their efforts.</p>
<p>Re-envisioning the administrative model is only one part of the capability-building puzzle. Among 18 occupation groups that employ workers with skills needed at nonprofits addressing homelessness (such as substance use disorder counselors and social service managers), 50 percent have a talent-supply shortage, representing more than 2,400 unfilled roles. Even within filled roles, employee turnover is a challenge, with 40 percent or more workers in 11 of the top occupation groups switching jobs in 2021.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d0da6ee6-3449-4b76-9d97-6273341faf4e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">84</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d0da6ee6-3449-4b76-9d97-6273341faf4e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Lightcast, accessed June 15, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> The private sector has a major opportunity to share learnings and best practices to support the homelessness ecosystem in developing, attracting, and retaining the right talent.</p>
<p>Private-sector companies can also offer broad secondments or externships for employees to work in the nonprofit sphere. Many organizations provide opportunities for employees to pursue temporary employment elsewhere, but adopting these programs more broadly and for smaller nonprofits in LA could provide a more targeted solution to talent shortages; research indicates secondments are effective in helping transfer knowledge and innovation to smaller organizations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f6fb07ea-9321-48ab-8fd2-26f1be854289"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">85</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f6fb07ea-9321-48ab-8fd2-26f1be854289" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Julian Decius, Christian Fechtelpeter, and Frederic Hilkenmeier, “How to foster innovation in SMEs: Evidence of the effectiveness of a project-based technology transfer approach,” <em>Journal of Technology Transfer</em>, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> This more collaborative approach to talent can help private-sector employees develop new skills and perspectives while helping nonprofits to fill critical gaps in positions and enact innovative approaches.</p>
<p>In summary, the following combined three actions could help make meaningful strides in addressing homelessness in LA:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Resourcing: Supporting at-risk employees.</em> What if every business in LA could help inform and connect their employees at risk of experiencing homelessness with the benefits they qualify for or—for select businesses—provide financial support on key issues such as housing?</li>
    <li><em>Reconfiguring: Diversifying talent pipelines to create employment opportunities for more Angelenos.</em> What if 20 percent of the businesses in LA with more than 100 employees committed to changing their talent-management practices to be more skills-based and to collaborating with local nonprofits to upskill and hire individuals experiencing homelessness in LA?</li>
    <li><em>Reimagining: Supporting the capabilities and talent of homelessness service providers.</em> What if 20 percent of the businesses in LA with more than 100 employees prioritized several nonprofits to systematically support by sharing knowledge and building skills?</li>
</ul>
<hr>
<p>While there is no shortage of commitment to ending this crisis among governments, corporations, and the people of LA, tailored, journey-based solutions that reflect the uniqueness of LA are required. Now is the moment for the private sector to spearhead efforts that unleash innovation within the homelessness ecosystem, redefine the future of economic opportunity, and offer support to the countless providers working within this space to deliver the progress that the LA community deserves.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/ashwin-adarkar">Ashwin Adarkar</a></strong> is a senior partner and manages McKinsey’s Southern California office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/tim-ward">Tim Ward</a></strong> and <strong><a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7b8d840caa-6a65-4626-8ce5-1f9fefe604dd%7d%40en">Lola Woetzel</a></strong> are senior partners, <strong>Tolian Gjika</strong> is a partner, and <strong>Yenli Wong</strong> is an associate partner.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Laura Hempton and Mallory Smith for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12
